Soldiers coerced the residents into giving them food.
The singer was coerced into a contract with the record company.

ans.value: a situation in which many people behave or react in an extreme or uncontrolled way because of fear, anger, etc.
without wasting more time;
different from what you would expect : not agreeing with what seems right or natural
As person who doesn't believe in god.

question: Caustic

ans.value: When a word or sentence used with a meaning that is different from it's literal meaning; "tons of work" or ""
a comparison of two things based on their being alike in some way
very harsh and critical
causing a feeling of great surprise or wonder : causing astonishment

examples: caustic film reviews
She wrote a caustic report about the decisions that led to the crisis.
caustic humor/wit

question: despair

ans.value: the feeling of no longer having any hope
a state of extreme happiness, especially when feeling pleasure:
the act of using someone unfairly for your own advantage
a short line with many curves : a short, wavy line.

examples: His despair nearly drove him mad.
She let out a cry of despair. [=desperation]
I was overcome by despair at being unable to find them.

question: Buttress

ans.value: to support, strengthen, or defend (something)
done before someone else can do it
a company that owns several smaller businesses whose products or services are usually very different:
a person who is killed or who suffers greatly for a religion, cause, etc.

examples: The treaty will buttress the cause of peace.
The theory has been buttressed by the results of the experiment.

question: Ramparts

ans.value: a tall, thick stone or dirt wall that is built around a castle, town, etc., to protect it from attacks
to know or guess about something before it happens:
to make something less clear and harder to understand, especially intentionally
the action of passing through or across a place.; the carrying of people or things from one place to another.

examples: The city's ramparts crumbled long ago.
